Posts.Content: Try aloe Vera shsmpo and conditioner from Holland and Barrett not cheap but very nourishing
Posts.Title: Shampoo

Posts.Content: I'm 3 years post chemo and still have very thin eyebrows. Any of you ladies got any suggestions on what I can do
Posts.Title: Eyrbrows still thin

Posts.Content: Any polish is good it forms a barrier on your nails but dark is best. I was told DO NOT have gels or extensions as they can lift your nails and cause infection which is the last thing you, and don't forget the tootsies
Posts.Title: Confused... light or dark nail varnish during chemo?

Posts.Content: As leolady said,  its bugger.  Lots of us have finished treatment but stay because of the friends (commonly known as fruit loops ) we've made. I had my MX almost 5 yrs ago and what an adventure I've had. Currently planning a return trip to new Zealand and Australia in January/February
Posts.Title: new patient

Posts.Content: There is a very interesting item in today's Daily Mail regarding spa treatments. A lot of us will have been lucky enough to have been offered various therapies at our respect units. A lot of these will have included massage of some sort. The volunteer therapists will have been trained and assessed by Macmillan.  Likewise the lovely breast nurses we see during treatment. For those of us unlucky enough to develop lymphoedema, these same nurses tell us that massage will help reduce the swelling and show us the best way to do this. The article highlights the problems encountered when it comes to using spa centres. A day, or even an hour or two, being pampered can be an oasis in dark days of treatment. But too many therapists and their employers are loath to even see cancer patients. So, Danny Bell (specialist advisor for treatment at Macmillan) says in one part of his response that massage can help and in another that massage may cause lymphoedema.  So why are we being told (by our Macmillan trained) nurses that massage can be a problem? Which is it?
Posts.Title: Conflicting Information

Posts.Content: Thanks to everyone for the clarification.  I really should have remembered that the Daily Mail is notorious for just printing those facts that fit their purpose and are not necessarily the full story
Posts.Title: Conflicting Information

Posts.Content: Try ASDA crop tops they are bril
Posts.Title: Best bra after sentinal lymph node biopsy

Posts.Content: Hate to say welcome but WELCOME.   This is probably the worst part , the time between diagnosis and starting treatment . Lots of ladies are quite poorly with chemo, but many cope well. I was one of the lucky ones. If you are well, have as many treats as you can. We did things like theatre, cinema and meals out. Weekends away are doable too.  Good luck sue
Posts.Title: Bombshell day

Posts.Content: AYou might want to check the 5 year letrozole . I have my mx about the time as you and I've been told it's 10 years
Posts.Title: letrozole hair thinning

Posts.Content: Oh Ali I hate yo burst your bubble  but for me BC and treatment was a stroll in the park. I was diagnosed  had chemo and RT and picked up where I left off a year later. I had very few SE and am very grateful. Since ten we've been to Mexico, Lanzarote and been lucky enough to see our beloved goddaughter get married in NZ and see cousins on OZ.  I wish everyone could be as lucky as me.
Posts.Title: PALB2

Posts.Content: I forgot to mention the flying lesson my lovely hubbie gave me for xmas. And my two wonderful bosom buddies met through the forum. so to all of you ladies out there just starting treatment, I hope it's good to you.
Posts.Title: PALB2

Posts.Content: Everyone I hear of you lovely ladies having problems I realise just how VERY lucky I have been.  Big hugs and kisses to everyone Sue

Posts.Content: I've been on letrozole for almost 4 years now without a single side effect and I've had just about every brand on the market
Posts.Title: Letrezol

Posts.Content: If you search in Macmillan web site there are several companies that do travel insurance for us BC ladies. I got mine through a company called IS. Hubby and I went to NZ and OZ last year for 4 weeks and paid £169 which given that he's 79+ wasn't too bad. They are also very sympathetic and lovely to talk to.  Where in OZ are you going? You'll have a fantastic time
Posts.Title: Travel Insurance.

Posts.Content: Can't help with the wig buying but the best swimwear is from ASDA (on line only nut true to size). You should check with your nurse about the swimming though.
Posts.Title: Where to buy wigs (I live in London)

Posts.Content: This had never been popular. There's nothing brace about choosing to have your head shaved.
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: We went to OZ & NZ this year and Mexico 2 years ago and it was never mentioned that taking letrozole while flying, and I checked with my BCN before booking. It was suggested (strongly) that I take low dose aspirin every 4 hours while flying. Flight socks are essential .
Posts.Title: Flying while on tamoxifen

Posts.Content: I'd like to add to this  aloa vera gel kept in the fridge is wonderful for sun stressed (or RT) skin

Posts.Content: Hi all, sorry you've all had problems with letrozole (and you will all hate me for this)  I've been taking letrozole for 3 years now, all brands, and haven't had a single side effect  I do symparthise with you poor girls and count myself  very very lucky

Posts.Title: GREAT TIMING......

Posts.Content: Hi new buddy. Food takes on a life of it's own during chemo. I found soft foods tasted like slime. I mostly existed on toast, tomato soup and cheese and crackers,  but eat what you fancy and little and often is best. You'll work out the best for you.
Posts.Title: Eating during FEC first week

Posts.Content: Glad it helped. The dietician at the hospital told me to forget the low fat stuff, you need your energy. Try swirling a little bit of cream through soup. I also made loads of homemade soup which is really good for you. I have got a book called The ROYAL MARSDEN COOKERY BOOK. That's got loads of useful stuff in it
Posts.Title: Eating during FEC first week

Posts.Content: Shaving it off was awful, but after that it was great fun. From the word go, it was never a secret and all and sundry saw me 'naked ' and I made a point of going to chemo like this.

Posts.Content: Four years ago I thought my wig looked good, but you look truly stunning. good luck for the future. sue

Posts.Content: Its your birthday, have a glass of something nice if you feel so inclined. I didn't give up alcohol while on treatment, I just couldn't taste it. Unless you've been told not to - why not. Happy Birthday
Posts.Title: Big birthday

Posts.Content: By now you have found out how much love there is on this site. You can join the families group for you and yours. But do get your mum to join for herself. Family is important but she'll have questions she might want to ask and not upset you. All our families have been where you are now so don't feel alone.
Posts.Title: My mum has just been diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: It's not much fun but you can do it. I was told to eat the same as if I was pregnant. All my favourite foods tasted awful and slimy in texture but that does go. Mouthwash is important as it helps prevent ulcers and thrush
Posts.Title: Morning ladies advice please.

Posts.Content: Contact Macmillan support they may be able to give you more (better) advice
Posts.Title: Morning ladies advice please.

Posts.Content: First of all good luck with the RT. Have you had your planning  meeting with the radiographer. She will advise what to use.  I found that when my skin started to react aloa vera gel kept in the fridge was amazing.
